Award.AwardTitle: Conserved transcriptional regulation of Drosophila aggression
Award.AbstractNarration:
Aggressive behavior is pervasive in the animal kingdom. It is the result of interactions between stimuli from the environment and internal activity of the brain. Although aggression is influenced by the environment, genetic differences between animals also play an important role in this behavior. In this project, aggression is studied in the laboratory fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster. Male fruit flies display obvious aggression responses in the presence of food territories and females. Even in the absence of these triggers, aggression can be observed albeit at lower frequency. The aggression responses are measured with simple and reproducible assays. Moreover, the fruit fly offers the advantage of a large number of genetic and neurobiological tools to analyze this behavior. Using these tools, the behavior will be dissected to better understand the mechanisms. Preliminary studies suggest that the basic molecular machinery regulating the drive to display aggression appears to be very similar between flies and mice. In addition, these studies also show that the neurons that regulate the behavior in the fruit fly are also surprisingly similar to neurons in mice that are known to regulate mammalian aggression. The function of the conserved machinery in these functionally similar neurons will be further studied in this series of experiments. These studies may identify a basic mechanism involved in the regulation of aggression in all animals.
These studies will drive the field of study of aggression in a new direction: from a main focus on hormonal control and modulation to transcriptional control in specific neuronal targets to integrate environmental responses that result in optimal adaptive behavior. The laboratory uses state of the art technology and resources for training the next generation of scientists. The lab actively participates in the training of minority students through the SMART program and the Houston Community College Science Intern Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aggressive behavior is a complex social behavior that depends on many genetic and non-genetic factors. While the role of several hormones, neurotransmitters and neuropeptides in aggression has been firmly established, much less is known regarding the role of transcriptional regulation in aggression. In addition, it is unclear whether mechanisms that regulate this behavior are common in all animals or whether these mechanisms are largely specific to individual species. In other words are mechanisms that govern aggression in humans the same as in mice or even more distantly related species like Drosophila melanogaster or laboratory fruit fly. Work in recent years has shown the power of Drosophila for the study of aggression. Aggression can be readily quantified in flies and genetic and neurobiological manipulation of this organism is unrivaled in biology. Against this backdrop we decided to assess whether we could the answer the question that perhaps some of the mechanisms regulating aggression in Drosophila show conservation in higher organisms. To do so we focused on transcriptional control of aggression. Transcription factors regulate suites of genes in the control of many biological processes. These control modules are often conserved between deeply divergent species in the control of development, physiology and behavior. In development, many examples exist of transcriptional control modules that regulate similar biological processes across many different species although there is also enormous evolutionary plasticity in deploying these regulatory pathways. In behavior, few transcriptional control modules have been identified. The most famous example is the control of biological rhythms. The first biological rhythm mutants were identified in Drosophila in the early seventies, and later molecularly characterized and found to be transcriptional regulators that control the clock. These clock components were subsequently shown to control the clock in nearly all living organisms.

To assess whether there exists a transcriptional control module that is important for the regulation of aggression in animals as divergent as flies and mammals, we investigated a transcriptional regulator that causes extreme aggression in mice when mutated. This transcription factor also exists in flies and is called Tailless. The tailless (tll) gene was first identified in Drosophila as a critical early developmental gene important for brain and tail development. The gene was later identified in mice where it was first shown to play an important role in brain development and later also shown to strongly affect aggression. To test whether tll affects aggression in flies, we knocked down the gene using RNA interference, and we found that flies with reduced Tll levels in the brain also had a strong aggression phenotype. We further showed that this effect is due to a role of the gene in the adult fly brain, and we found that Tll is localized to a small set of adult neurons, called the pars intercerebralis. This finding is exciting because this brain region is similar in function to the mammalian hypothalamus and shows similar developmental regulation and similar structural connections. A large body of research has shown that the mammalian hypothalamus is very important in the regulation of aggression in nearly all mammals investigated, including humans. We further showed that the role of Tll in aggression occurs through the cells in the pars intercerebralis (PI). These neurons are neurosecretory and release a number of neuropeptides, many of which are currently not very well characterized.
